Education Master Teacher of Acting at the Experimental Theatre Wing in the Department of Drama, where he has taught at ETW for twenty years. MFA, NYU. Biography His book An Acrobat of the Heart , a physical approach to acting inspired by the works of Jerzy Grotowski, was published by Vintage Books in September, 2000. He was the dramaturg for Moisés Kaufman's Gross Indecency , T he Three Trials of Oscar Wilde , and Asscoiate Writer for The Laramie Project . His other plays include Class! (with Jon Lipsky), Calamity! (with Suzanne Baxtresser), The Dragon , and Goin' Downtown . He has directed in Boston, where he was Artistic Director of Reality Theater, and in New York where he was Artistic Director of The New York Free Theater. His productions at NYU include Ubu Roi , Mass Transit , Troilus and Cressida, and The Merchant of Venice . Physical Approach to Acting - Stephen Wangh                    Stephen Wangh         Menu           Author        An Acrobat of the Heart             Excerpts       Reviews/Comments       Buy Now                 The Heart of Teaching             Excerpts       Reviews/Comments       Buy Now                 Articles          Playwright     Acting Teacher           History      Workshops      Acrobatics of the Heart         Director                  What is a physical approach to acting?      Konstantin Stanislavski's early research into acting technique led him to develop many inner, psychological and memory-centered exercises. But later in his career, Stanislavski concentrated much more on physical action. In the book Creating a Role he wrote:   ...with faith in your physical actions you will feel emotions, akin to the external life of your part, which possess a logical bond with your soul.... Your body is biddable; feelings are capricious.   In the 1960's Jerzy Grotowski built upon this late work of Stanislavski's. At the Polish Laboratory Theater, Grotowski experimented with mime, with Meyerhold's biomechanics and with Asian theater exercises. But he felt that these practices tended to impose an "artificial system of signs" upon the actor, so Grotowski and his actors at the Polish Laboratory developed a more organic approach.  They searched for exercises to help actors overcome their own individual acting limitations. The working methods they developed were not "techniques" but rather forms designed to help an actor to uncover the emotional truths locked within his or her own muscular memory and physical impulses.   Since studying with Grotowski in 1967, I have been working to make this physical approach to acting practical and accessible for American actors. An Acrobat of the Heart combines a study of Grotowski's plastique and corporel exercises with work drawn from Kristin Linklater, Spolin Theater Games, and other sources to lead acting students on a journey from basic physical training exercises to scene and character work. Stephen Wangh, Author of "An Acrobat of the Heart: A Physical Approach to Acting" and "The Heart of Teaching"                    Stephen Wangh         Menu           Author        An Acrobat of the Heart             Excerpts       Reviews/Comments       Buy Now                 The Heart of Teaching             Excerpts       Reviews/Comments       Buy Now                 Articles          Playwright     Acting Teacher           History      Workshops      Acrobatics of the Heart         Director                   Home     Upcoming Events    July 12 - 26, 2015:     Acrobatics of the Heart : A two-week immersion in Grotowski-based physical acting training in the Berkshire mountains with master teacher Stephen Wangh and co-teachers Raïna von Waldenburg, Wendy vanden Heuvel, and Erica Fae.   Learn More |   Request Info         Stephen Wangh , has been a playwright , director , and teacher of acting . He is the author of An Acrobat of the Heart, a physical approach to acting inspired by the work of Jerzy Grotowski (Vintage, Random House, 2000) and of The Heart of Teaching: Empowering Students in the Performing Arts (Routledge, 2012).   He is the author of 15 plays, and was one of the writers of The People’s Temple (Glickman award: Best play in the Bay Area, 2005). He was Associate Writer for The Laramie Project (Emmy nomination 2002), and dramaturg of Moisés Kaufman’s Gross Indecency, the three trials of Oscar Wilde (1997).   Stephen now teaches the Acrobatics of the Heart immersive summer training for performers. And he leads seminars and workshops on the Inner Dynamics of Teaching for teachers of the performing arts.     Recent Press    The Heart of Teaching: Empowering Students in the Performing Arts “[Wangh's] goal is to leap into the thorniest of situations in order to propose methods for harnessing the power found there and to liberate his students and himself from static thinking and the atrophying effects of habitual behavior, which for actors can lead to creative dead-ends and for teachers can ossify into a stultifying pedagogy.” - TDR     Recent Lecture     Revenge, Forgiveness and the Responsibility of the Witness  March 23, 2013  The Chicago Association for Psychoanalytic Psychology  Association for Psychoanalytic Psychology  Read PDF now            Workshops and Lectures   Biography     Contact   Related Websites             This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©       by Stephen Wangh.
